The '''Middle Marches''', also known as the '''Mittelmarch''', are a fictional land found in the [[Von Bek]] series of novels written by [[Michael Moorcock]]. They are described as "the world in between heaven and ours".<ref>{{cite book|title=The City in the Autumn Stars|publisher=Ace|page=115}}</ref>
The ''Middle Marches'': historically, the name of part of the border area between England and Scotland which was the scene of frequent raids and incursions throughout the Middle Ages and into the 17th century. See [[Scottish Marches]]
== Footnotes == <references />
[[Category:Michael Moorcock locations]] [[Category:Fictional countries]]

{{advert|date=July 2018}} {{refimprove|date=July 2018}} '''Moviment Graffitti''' is a [[Malta|Maltese]] [[pressure group]] promoting an amalgamation of [[leftist]] sociopolitical ideas, mainly [[human rights]], [[social equality|equality]], [[environmentalism]] and [[anti-fascism]]. It was founded in 1994.<ref>https://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/national/86137/moviment_graffitti_since_1994_fighting_the_power#.WwZjHUiFOUk</ref>
== Ideals and Objectives ==
Moviment Graffitti stands for social justice, equality and sustainability. This entails supporting and lobbying for fairer workers’ rights such as an increase in the minimum wage and working towards a new and equal economic system in which exploitation has no place. This includes standing against the destruction of the environment, illegal developments and the privatisation of public spaces.
Moviment Graffitti stands for the well-being of all humanity and thus, for the right of migration for all and against a world with man-made borders. An important part of standing for a more just world is actively working to eradicate racism and xenophobia by organising actions and information campaigns as well as pushing for migrants’ rights. One campaign that the movement feels strongly about is showing international solidarity with the plight of Palestinians by raising awareness of the cruel and constant injustice and discrimination they face everyday at the hands of the Israeli state.
== How their goals are achieved ==
Moviment Graffitti utilizes a number of different strategies in its work. It has often taken a pro-active role in forming coalitions and building networks that bring together different organisations and individuals to work as a common front on issues such as racism, destruction of natural landscape and animal rights. It has regularly supported workers’ struggles and voiced its stance in favour of workers’ rights.
Moviment Graffitti frequently holds awareness-raising campaigns where it distributes information and engages in discussions in public spaces and other venues such as University, schools and youth centres.
Direct actions are also used to draw the public’s attention to specific issues. These consist in activities like banner-drops and sit-ins. Moviment Graffitti has also coordinated several protests in relation to pressing issues being faced at a particular point in time, such as war, racist incidents and projects damaging the environment.
Decisions within the movement are taken during regular meetings where anyone who shares the organisation’s vision and principles can attend and contribute. Moviment Graffitti’s activities are self-funded by the organisation through membership-payment and fund-raising events held throughout the year.
==Campaigns Run== *Against Hilton Development with Front Kontra l-Hilton (1994-1997) *Anti MacDonald’s Day (1995-2000) *Verdala Golf course with Front Kontra l-Golf Kors (2000-2004) *Took part in Anti Acta Protest (2012) *Solidarity with Palestinians march (2012) *Solidarity with Palestinians march (2014) *Gathering in favor of YES vote in 2015 Greek referendum (2015) *Nakba Commemoration Gathering in Valletta (2015) *Zonqor AUM development with Front Harsien ODZ (2015) *Commemoration of killing of four boys in Gaza beach in 2014 Israel-Gaza war (July 2015) *Manoel Island with Kamp Emergenza Ambjent (2016-2018) <ref>https://www.tvm.com.mt/en/news/activists-force-open-barriers-camp-on-manoel-island/</ref> *Paceville Masterplan with Kamp Emergenza Ambjent (2016-2017) <ref>http://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2016-11-07/local-news/This-masterplan-should-be-scrapped-immediately-Residents-and-NGOs-band-together-against-project-6736166284</ref> *Increase in Minimum Wage (2017 - 2018) <ref>https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20161029/local/campaign-for-decent-minimum-wage-launched.629402</ref> *Rent Control Proposal (2018) <ref>http://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2018-02-25/local-news/17-member-coalition-propose-rent-regulation-for-a-fairer-society-6736185305</ref>
==References== <references />
==External links== * [http://www.movimentgraffitti.org/index.php Moviment Graffitti Website] - Dead website link
[[Category:Political advocacy groups in Malta]]

<!--... Attention: THIS IS AN OUTLINE
part of the set of 740+ outlines listed at [[Portal:Contents/Outlines]].
Wikipedia outlines are a special type of list article. They make up one of Wikipedia's content navigation systems
See [[Wikipedia:Outlines]] for more details. Further improvements to this outline are on the way ...--> {{Use British English|date=March 2016}} {{double image|right|Flag of Gibraltar.svg|224|Coat of arms of Gibraltar.svg|98|The [[Flag of Gibraltar]]|The [[Coat of arms of Gibraltar]]}} [[File:Location Gibraltar EU.png|thumb|The location of [[Gibraltar]] within the [[European Union]]]] [[File:Gibraltar map-en.svg|thumb|A detailed map of [[Gibraltar]]]]
The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to Gibraltar:
'''[[Gibraltar]]''' – [[British Overseas Territories|British Overseas Territory]] located near the southernmost tip of the [[Iberian Peninsula]] of Southeastern [[Europe]] overlooking the [[Strait of Gibraltar]] between the [[Mediterranean Sea]] and the [[North Atlantic Ocean]].<ref name=CIA_World_Factbook>{{cite web|date=July 2, 2009|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/gi.html|title=Gibraltar|work=[[The World Factbook]]|publisher=[[United States]] [[Central Intelligence Agency]]|accessdate=July 23, 2009}}</ref> The territory shares a border with [[Spain]] to the north. Gibraltar was ceded by Spain to [[Great Britain]] in perpetuity in 1713 under the [[Treaty of Utrecht]] though Spain requests its return. The [[Government of the United Kingdom]] has stated it is committed to respecting the wishes of the [[Gibraltarian people|Gibraltarians]],<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20160303235215/http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200708/cmselect/cmfaff/uc147-v/uc14702.htm Uncorrected evidence]</ref> who strongly oppose the idea of annexation along with any proposal for shared sovereignty with Spain.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/country_profiles/3851047.stm|title=Regions and territories: Gibraltar|accessdate=2007-12-20|date=2007-07-18|publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/gibraltar/story/0,,634007,00.html|title=Gibraltar|author=Mark Oliver|accessdate=2007-12-20|author2=Sally Bolton |author3=Jon Dennis |author4=Matthew Tempest |date=August 4, 2004|publisher=[[Guardian Unlimited]]}}</ref>
{{TOC limit|limit=2}}
==General reference== * {{IPAc-en|dʒ|ᵻ|ˈ|b|r|ɒ|l|t|ər}} * Common English country name: [[Gibraltar]] * Official English country name: [[Gibraltar]]<ref>[http://www.gibraltar.gov.gi/constitution/new_constitution/NewGibraltarConstitution.pdf Gibraltar Constitution Order 2006] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081121050613/http://www.gibraltar.gov.gi/constitution/new_constitution/NewGibraltarConstitution.pdf |date=November 21, 2008 }}</ref> * Common [[endonym]](s): [[List of countries and capitals in native languages]] None * Official endonym(s): [[List of official endonyms of present-day nations and states]] None * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Adjectival]](s): [[Gibraltar]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Official demonym]](s): [[Gibraltarian people|Gibraltarians]] * Unofficial demonym(s): [[Llanito#Demonym|Llanitos]] * [[Etymology]]: [[Gibraltar#Etymology|Etymology of Gibraltar]] * [[ISO country codes]]: GI, GIB, 292 * [[ISO region codes]]: See [[ISO 3166-2:GI]] * [[Internet]] [[country code top-level domain]]: [[.gi]] * [[List of country calling codes|International dialing Code]]: 350
==Geography of Gibraltar== [[File:Rock of Gibraltar northwest.jpg|thumb|250px|View of the western face of the [[Rock of Gibraltar]].]] [[File:Bay of Gibraltar.jpg|thumb|250px|An enlargeable satellite image of the [[Bay of Gibraltar]]]] [[File:Surface of the Strait of Gibraltar.png|thumb|250px|Topographic/hydrographic map of the [[Strait of Gibraltar]]]] [[File:Gibraltar Rock 03.jpg|thumb|250px|View of [[North Africa]] across the Strait of Gibraltar as seen from The Rock.]]
[[Geography of Gibraltar]] * Gibraltar is: a [[British Overseas Territories|British Overseas Territory]] * Land boundaries: {{Flag|Spain}} {{convert|1.2|km|mi}} * Coastline: [[Mediterranean Sea]] {{convert|12|km|mi}} * [[Demographics of Gibraltar|Population of Gibraltar]]: 28,875 * [[Area of Gibraltar]]: {{convert|6.843|km2|sqmi}} * [[:commons:Atlas of Gibraltar|Atlas of Gibraltar]]
===Location of Gibraltar=== * Gibraltar is situated within the following regions: ** [[Northern Hemisphere]] and [[Western Hemisphere]] ** [[Eurasia]] *** [[Europe]] **** [[Southern Europe]] ***** [[Iberian Peninsula]] - near its southernmost tip, overlooking the [[Strait of Gibraltar]] ** [[Time zone]]: [[Central European Time]] ([[UTC+01]]), [[Central European Summer Time]] ([[UTC+02]]) * Extreme points of Gibraltar ** High: [[Rock of Gibraltar]] {{convert|426|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} ** Low: [[Strait of Gibraltar]] 0 m
===Environment of Gibraltar===
* [[The weather in Gibraltar|Climate of Gibraltar]] ** [[Water supply and sanitation in Gibraltar]] * [[Rock of Gibraltar|Geology of Gibraltar]] ** [[Azores–Gibraltar Transform Fault]] * Protected areas of Gibraltar ** [[Gibraltar Botanic Gardens]] * [[Wildlife of Gibraltar]] ** [[Flora of Gibraltar]] ** [[Fauna of Gibraltar]] *** [[List of birds of Gibraltar|Birds of Gibraltar]] *** [[List of mammals in Gibraltar|Mammals of Gibraltar]] *** [[List of reptiles and amphibians in Gibraltar|Reptiles and amphibians of Gibraltar]]
====Natural geographic features of Gibraltar====
* [[Rock of Gibraltar]] – one of the two [[Pillars of Hercules]] * [[Bay of Gibraltar]] * [[Great Gibraltar Sand Dune|Sand Dune]] * [[Strait of Gibraltar]] * [[World Heritage Sites in Gibraltar]]: None, though the entire peninsula was once a proposed World Heritage Site <ref>{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/697/ |title=Gibraltar defences |publisher=Whc.unesco.org |accessdate=2010-12-28}}</ref> In May 2012, the [[Gorham's Cave]] complex (including [[Vanguard Cave]]) made the United Kingdom's short list of sites that have been forwarded for submission to [[UNESCO]].

revision.text:
'''Reflector''' (反光鏡楽隊) is a rock band that formed in [[Beijing]] in 1997. According to the band's official English language [[website]], Reflector has been featured on [[CNN]] and in ''[[Newsweek]]'' magazine. Reflector lists among its English language musical influences the bands [[Green Day]], [[NOFX]] and [[Lagwagon]]. In 2000 their song "Scream Club" was featured in the movie ''[[Warm Summer Day]]''.
In 2001 Reflector became one of the first of bands (which many in China consider to be "punk") from [[China]] to tour the [[United States]]; the band performed in seven West Coast cities, including a gig in [[Sacramento]] opening for former punk band [[Anti-Flag]].
The band performed at [[Cui Jian]]'s 2003 [[Live Vocals festival]], and in the [[Midi Music Festival|2003 Midi Music Festival]].
==Personnel== *Tian Jianhua aka "Tj" - Bass/Vocals *Li Peng - Guitar/Vocals *Ye Jingying - Drums/Background Vocals
==Discography== *1999 - [[Wuliao Contingent]] compilation, 8 songs *2002 - [[Reflector (ep)|Reflector]] ep on [[People's Records]]
==External links== *{{en icon}} {{ja icon}} {{zh icon}} [http://www.reflectorband.com/en/main.htm Reflector official site] *{{ja icon}} [http://www.yaogun.com/artist/punk/reflector.htm Reflector at Yaogun Chinese Rock Database]
[[Category:Chinese punk rock groups]] [[Category:Musical groups from Beijing]]

{{Infobox Single | Name = Shadows| Cover = Shadows (Breed 77 song) cover.jpg| Artist = [[Breed 77]] | Album = [[Breed 77 (album)|Breed 77]] | Released = 31 January 2005 ([[United Kingdom]]) | Recorded = 2005 | Genre = [[Metal music|Metal]], [[flamenco music|Flamenco]] | Label = [[Albert Productions]] | Last single = "[[World's on Fire (song)|World's on Fire]]"
(2004) | This single = "Shadows"
(2005) | Next single = "Alive"
(2006) | | Misc = }} "'''Shadows'''" is a song and single by [[Gibraltarian people|Gibraltarian]] [[flamenco]] [[metal music|metal]] band [[Breed 77]] which first appeared on the ''[[Breed 77 (album)|Breed 77]]'' album. It was released in three different formats: a double A-side CD with an acoustic version of "Breaking the Silence"; an enhanced CD including the video and remixes; and a double A-side vinyl which features a "Metal Mix" of both "Shadows" and "A Matter of Time" ([[Cultura (Breed 77 album)|Cultura]]). "Shadows" just failed to reach the [[UK Singles Charts|UK Top 40]] by a small margin, attaining only number 42. Track 1 & 2 (CDs) were written by [[Paul Isola]], [[Danny Felice]], [[Stuart Cavilla]] and [[Pete Chichone]]. Track 2 (vinyl) was written by Danny Felice, Paul Isola, [[Pedro Caparros]] and Stu Cavilla. The line-up for this single consisted of Paul Isola, Danny Felice, Stuart Cavilla, Pete Chichone and Pedro Caparros.[http://www.stannescastle.co.uk/breed77/releases/shadows.htm "Shadows" info from Breed 77's unofficial website] ==Track listing== # "Shadows Sombras Latinas" # "Shadows" (Mayhem Mix) # "Shadows" (Metal Mix 2005) # "Breaking the Silence" (Acústico) # "A Matter of Time" (Metal Mix 2005) ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Breed 77}} [[Category:2005 singles]] [[Category:Breed 77 songs]] [[Category:2005 songs]] [[Category:Albert Productions singles]] {{2000s-metal-album-stub}} {{Gibraltar-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox ethnic group |group = Soninké people |image = [[Image:GuerriersSarrakholais.jpg|200px]] |caption = Soninke soldiers, 1890. |pop = ~2 million |popplace = [[Mali]], [[Mauritania]], [[Sénégal]], [[Côte d'Ivoire]], [[Burkina Faso]], [[Ghana]], [[the Gambia]], [[Guinea]], [[Guinea-Bissau]]{{cite book|author=Diagram Group|title=Encyclopedia of African Peoples|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xJQuAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT825|year=2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-96341-5|page=825}} |rels = [[Islam]] |langs = [[Soninke language]], French, English, Portuguese |related = [[Mandinka people]], [[Bambara people]], [[Imraguen people|Imraguen]], [[Jakhanke]] }} The '''Soninke''', also called '''Sarakole''', '''Seraculeh''', or '''Serahuli''', are a [[West Africa]]n ethnic group found in eastern [[Senegal]] and its capital [[Dakar]], northwestern [[Mali]] and Foute Djalon in [[Guinea]], and southern [[Mauritania]].{{cite book|author=Ralph A. Austen|title=In Search of Sunjata: The Mande Oral Epic as History, Literature and Performance|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lnxj5k40y7UC&pg=PA143 |year=1999|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=0-253-33452-7|page=143}} They speak the [[Soninke language]], also called ''Maraka'' language, which is one of the [[Mande language]]s.{{cite book|author=Andrew Dalby|title=Dictionary of Languages: The Definitive Reference to More Than 400 Languages|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yKSeVLghcfQC&pg=PA574 |year=1998|publisher=Columbia University Press |isbn=978-0-231-11568-1|page=574}} Soninke people were the founders of the ancient [[Ghana Empire|empire of Ghana]] c. AD 750-1240. Subgroups of Soninke include the [[Maraka]] and [[Soninke Wangara|Wangara]]. When the Ghana empire dispersed, the resulting [[diaspora]] brought Soninkes to Mali, Senegal, Mauritania, Gambia, Burkina Faso, [[Ghana]], and [[Guinea-Bissau]] where some of this trading diaspora was called Wangara.{{cite book|author=John O. Hunwick|title=Timbuktu and the Songhay Empire: Al-Saʿdi's Taʾrīkh Al-Sūdān Down to 1613 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kdEsWyzLnD8C |year=2003|publisher=BRILL Academic|isbn=90-04-12822-0|pages=xxviii with footnote 18}} Predominantly Muslims, the Soninke were one of the early ethnic groups from Sub-Saharan [[West Africa]] to convert to [[Islam]] in about the 10th century. The contemporary population of Soninke people is estimated to be over 2 million. The cultural practices of Soninke people are similar to the [[Mandé]] peoples, and those of the [[Imraguen people|Imraguen]] of Mauritania. It includes traditional Islamic rites of marriage(s), circumcision and social stratification. ==History== {{Main|History of the Soninke people}} [[Image:BakelDiobé.jpg|thumb|right|Diobé, ruler of Soninke colonial era town of [[Bakel, Senegal|Bakel]], with his advisors (1887-1888)]] Archaeological evidence suggests that the regions where Soninke people are found were inhabited in ancient times. These stone settlements were built on the rocky promontories of Tichit-Walata and the Tagant cliffs of Southern Mauritania. However, there are no surviving records to suggest which ethnic group these people were, but the settlers of this region by between 1000 BCE and 600 BCE were likely related to the Soninke people. A significant agro-pastoral society had developed in this prehistoric era. According to Soninke [[oral tradition]] history, the ancestor of the Soninke was Dinga, who came from the Middle East.{{cite book|author=David C. Conrad|title=Empires of Medieval West Africa: Ghana, Mali, and Songhay|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mP2KSOvJHbMC&pg=PA25 |year=2009|publisher=Infobase|isbn=978-1-60413-164-2|pages=25 }}, Quote: "The legend often begins by describing how the ancestor Dinga came from somewhere in the Middle East." His sons included Dyabe Sisse, the founder of the Wagadu kingdom with its capital at [[Koumbi Saleh|Kumbi]].{{cite book|last1=Levtzion|first1=Nehemia| title=Ancient Ghana and Mali|date=1973|publisher=Methuen & Co Ltd|location=New York|isbn=0841904316|pages=16–18, 21}} Another Soninke tradition indicates that they migrated from [[Aswan]], [[Ancient Egypt|Egypt]].{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uivtCqOlpTsC&pg=PA104&dq=cisse+aswan&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjc_M6G587XAhVFRN8KHTOIDqAQ6AEIKzAB#v=onepage&q=cisse+aswan&f=false|title=Encyclopedia of African American History [3 volumes]|first1=Leslie M.|last1=Alexander|first2=Walter C. Rucker|last2=Jr|date=9 February 2010|publisher=ABC-CLIO|accessdate=25 April 2018|via=Google Books}} The early written records about Soninke come from early Islamic historians. The Soninke, according to these records, were the founders of the ancient [[Ghana Empire]] (not to be confused with modern Ghana), also called the Wagadu Empire. This empire has roots in the 5th-century CE and was destroyed by about the 12th century,{{cite book|author=David C. Conrad|title=Empires of Medieval West Africa: Ghana, Mali, and Songhay|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mP2KSOvJHbMC&pg=PA25 |year=2009|publisher=Infobase|isbn=978-1-60413-164-2|pages=23–25 }} after the Muslim invasions of this region started in the 10th-century.[https://www.britannica.com/topic/Soninke Soninke people] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161105232659/https://www.britannica.com/topic/Soninke |date=2016-11-05 }}, Encyclopædia Britannica, Quote: "The Soninke were the founders of the ancient empire of Ghana, which was destroyed after the invasions of Muslim conquerors in the 10th century".{{cite book|author=Kevin Shillington|title=History of Africa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YdscBQAAQBAJ|year=2012|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=978-1-137-00333-1|pages=88–89}} ==Demographics and distribution== [[Image:Soninke.gif|thumb|right|Map of the Soninke population centers in Mali]] In contemporary time, the total population of Soninke people is above 2 million. Soninke people are found throughout West Africa and in France, given their migration when Senegal and Mali were a part of the French colonial empire. Most of the Soninke people are found in the valley of the upper [[Senegal river]] and along the Mali – Senegal – Mauritania border between [[Nara, Mali|Nara]] and [[Nioro du Sahel]]. Migrations under [[French West Africa|French colonial rule]] have led many Soninke to build communities in [[Dakar]], other cities in Africa and in France. Soninke community were the early settlers in France, their community is found in [[Paris, France|Paris]] and in southern French cities, and their language is the primary dialect spoken among many Muslim communities of France. There are also many Soninke living in cities throughout [[Central Africa]], a population that includes new migrants as well as descendants of migration dating back to the 1800s, such as the [[laptot]]s who represented French mercantile and colonial interests in the region.{{cite book|author=François Manchuelle|title=Willing Migrants: Soninke Labor Diasporas, 1848-1960|url=http://www.ohioswallow.com/book/Willing+Migrants|year=1997|publisher=Ohio University Press|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171002022744/http://www.ohioswallow.com/book/Willing+Migrants|archivedate=2017-10-02|df=}} Trade networks led by the ''Wangara'' mercantile confederations, spread Soninke people and culture throughout most of Mali and Senegal, southern Mauritania, northern Burkina Faso, as well as parts of [[the Gambia]], and Guinea-Bissau. The '''Maraka''' - Soninke merchant communities and plantations (centered just north of the city of [[Segou]], Mali) were an economic mainspring under the [[Bambara Empire]], and built trade routes in the West Africa region.{{Citation needed|date=November 2016}} ==Religion== The Soninke people were a coastal trade link between the Berber people of [[Maghreb]] and the Empires in sub-Saharan West Africa. In their early history, they helped exchange salt from the north and western coast for gold found inland.{{cite book|author=Kevin Shillington|title=History of Africa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YdscBQAAQBAJ|year=2012|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=978-1-137-00333-1|pages=90–92}} This trade brought Muslim traders to them, particularly Arab traders interested in gold, after Islam arrived in North Africa. The earliest passing mention of Soninke people's Ghana Empire is found in the 8th-century Arab geographer [[Muḥammad ibn Ibrāhīm al-Fazārī]] and a more complete record found in another 11th-century Arab geographer [[Al-Bakri]]. The rulers and Soninke people of the Ghana Empire converted to Islam in the 11th century, and they have been Muslim ever since. Some Islamic sources suggest that the conversion was triggered after the 1076 [[Almoravid]] conquest of the Empire of Ghana.Asante, Molefi Kete. ''The History of Africa: The Quest for Eternal Harmony''. New York: Routledge, 2007. 121-2. The Soninke people, like other Mande peoples, subscribe to the [[Maliki]] school of [[Sunni]] Islam.{{cite book|author=John A. Shoup|title=Ethnic Groups of Africa and the Middle East: An Encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SPBfnT_E1mgC |year=2011|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-59884-362-0|pages=183–184}} ==Society and culture== [[File:SarrakholaisCaravanier.jpg|thumb|180px|A Soninke man in 1890, sketched by M Philippe]] The Soninke society and its culture has historically many cultural practices with its neighboring ethnic groups, particularly the Mande peoples. This includes the religion of Islam, occupations, foods, the rites of passage, family structure, weddings and social stratification. ===Social stratification=== Soninke society, like other groups in Mande and beyond, is shaped by various forms of social stratification.{{cite journal|author=Haddy Tunkara-Bah|year= 2016|title= Sociocultural factors influencing fertility among the Soninke| journal=African Renaissance| volume=13| number= 1-2|pages= 31–44}}, Quote: "The Soninke society in the Gambia is primarily rural and highly gender-stratified culture. (...) In the Soninke social organization everyone occupies a place."{{cite journal| author= Tal Tamari| year= 1991| title= The Development of Caste Systems in West Africa| journal= The Journal of African History| volume= 32| number= 2| pages= 221–250| publisher= Cambridge University Press| jstor= 182616| doi= 10.1017/s0021853700025718}}Monica Bella (1987), [http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.543.3564&rep=rep1&type=pdf AFRICA STUDIES: THE EXPLORATION OF ALTERNATIVE LAND TENURE AND ORGANIZATIONAL ARRANGEMENTS FOR THE BAKEL SMALL IRRIGATED PERIMETERS] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171118234652/http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.543.3564&rep=rep1&type=pdf |date=2017-11-18 }}, University of Wisconsin-Madison, United States Agency for International Development, Quote:"Soninke society is not egalitarian, but rather is stratified into castes. At the top there is the noble or hore caste. The hore consist of debeaumme, nyinvaaumme, and the marabouts or religious leaders. The power of the marabouts is less than that of other nobles. Next are the artisan castes or nyakhamala. ...";
{{cite book|author=Edouard François Manchuelle|title=Background to Black African Emigration to France: The Labor Migrations of the Soninke, 1848-1987|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FDnxAAAAMAAJ|year=1987|publisher=University of California Press|pages=50–52}} The Soninke strata have included a free category called ''Horro'' or ''Horon'', a caste system category called ''Namaxala'' or ''[[Nyamakala|Nyaxamalo]]'', and slaves called ''Komo''.{{cite book|author= Michael Gomez|title=Pragmatism in the Age of Jihad: The Precolonial State of Bundu|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gfhGouf7_TsC |year=2002 |publisher= Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-52847-4| page=24}}{{cite book|author=Sean Hanretta|title=Islam and Social Change in French West Africa: History of an Emancipatory Community |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9Fj79QbyRJUC&pg=PA37 |year=2009|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-89971-0|pages=37 with footnote 23 }} In the Jaara subgroup of the Soninke people, the nobility called ''Tunkanlenmu'' was another strata.Mamadou Lamine Diawara (1990), La Graine de la Parole: dimension sociale et politique des traditions orales du royaume de Jaara (Mali) du XVème au milieu du XIXème siècle, volume 92, Franz Steiner Verlag Wiesbaden GmbH, pages 35-37, 41-45 The Soninke society became highly stratified after the thirteenth century.{{cite book|author=Tal Tamari|editor=David C. Conrad and Barbara E. Frank|title=Status and Identity in West Africa: Nyamakalaw of Mande|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JzeVS6pYS7YC |year=1995|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=0-253-11264-8|pages=61–63}} The slaves were the largest strata, one at the bottom among the Soninke like other West African ethnic groups, and constituted up to half of the population. The slaves among the Soninke people were hierarchically arranged into three strata. The village slaves were a privileged servile group who lived apart from the village and took orders from the village chief. The domestic slaves lived in with a family and could not be sold. The lowest level among slaves were the trade slaves who could be bought and sold. With time, each of these strata became [[endogamous]], states Daniel Littlefield, a professor of history.{{cite book|author=Daniel C. Littlefield|title=Rice and Slaves |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZEO5lLG95lMC&pg=PA79 |year=1991|publisher=University of Illinois Press|isbn=978-0-252-06214-8|pages=79 footnote 11}} Above the slaves were the castes of Soninke, which too were hereditary, endogamous and had an embedded hierarchical status. They included, for example, the ''garanke'' (leather workers) below the ''fune'' (bard), the ''fune'' below the ''gesere'' or ''jeli'' (griots, singers), the ''jeli'' below the ''tage'' or ''numu'' (smiths, pottery workers).{{cite book|author=Barbara G. Hoffman|title=Griots at War: Conflict, Conciliation, and Caste in Mande|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N420DztTNJMC |year=2001|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=0-253-10893-4|pages=8, 10–12, 30–31, 35–36, 235–240, 246, 269–270 note 31}} The castes and slaves system of Soninke may be linked. According to Susan McIntosh, a professor of anthropology specializing in African societies, archeological evidence shows that Arabs and Berbers had expanded and established an integrated sub-Saharan trade and transport network with West Africa, building upon the pre-existing trade routes through Western Sudan.{{cite book|author=Susan McIntosh|editor=Christopher R. DeCorse|title=West Africa During the Atlantic Slave Trade: Archaeological Perspectives |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8Fcr1HSZXNgC |year=2001|publisher=Bloomsbury Academic|isbn=978-0-7185-0247-8|pages=17–18}} This trade, by the 9-10th centuries, states McIntosh, included commodities and slaves. The reach of slave trading had extended into [[Ghana]] and the western Atlantic coast by the 11th century, and the slave raiding, capture, holding and trading systems became increasingly sophisticated in 13th and 14th century Mali Empire and 16th century Songhai Empire. As the practice of slavery grew, so did the caste system. Tamari suggests that a corollary of the rising slavery system was the development and growth of the caste system among numerous ethnic groups of Africa by about the 13th century.{{cite journal | last=Tamari | first=Tal | title=The Development of Caste Systems in West Africa | journal=The Journal of African History | publisher=Cambridge University Press | volume=32 | issue=02 | year=1991 | pages=221–250 | doi=10.1017/s0021853700025718 }} McIntosh concurs with Tamari, but states that the emergence of caste systems likely occurred much earlier in the West African societies such as Soninke, Mande, Malinke, Wolof, Serer, and others. She places the development and spread of castes in these societies to about the 10th-century, because the slave capture, slave trade and slave holding by elite families was an established institution in West Africa by then, and slavery created a template for servile relationships and social stratification of human beings. The linguistic evidence suggests that stratification structure relating to caste system and slavery likely were shared between the Manding and Soninke people, and possibly some others such as the Dogon people of West Africa.{{cite book|author=Tal Tamari|editor=David C. Conrad and Barbara E. Frank|title=Status and Identity in West Africa: Nyamakalaw of Mande|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JzeVS6pYS7YC |year=1995|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=0-253-11264-8|pages=65–67, 71–73}} However, the linguistic differences between the caste and slave systems between Soninke and northern ethnic groups of Africa such as the Tuareg people and Moors suggests that these evolved separately.{{cite book|author=Tal Tamari|editor=David C. Conrad and Barbara E. Frank|title=Status and Identity in West Africa: Nyamakalaw of Mande|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JzeVS6pYS7YC |year=1995|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=0-253-11264-8|pages=68–69}} ===Marriage=== [[File:Boilat-22-Femme sarackoullée.jpg|thumb|180px|A Soninke woman, an 1853 sketch by David Boilat]] Marriage in Soninke society has followed Islamic practices. Cousin marriages are common and preferred in Soninke culture, just as with the [[Fula people]].{{cite book|author=Saskia Brand|title=Mediating Means and Fate: A Socio-Political Analysis of Fertility and Demographic Change in Bamako, Mali |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RZdrxQRXE7AC&pg=PA69|year=2001|publisher=BRILL Academic|isbn=90-04-12033-5|pages=69–71}} Parents consent to marriage. A traditional proverb states, "Cousins are made for each other." The practice among Soninke merchants, states Saskia Brand, a professor of psychology and educational sciences, may be related to the cultural belief that cousin marriages "helps to keep the money in the family". If both families agree, the couple is engaged (''i na tamma laga'') in a [[mosque]]. Each month after the engagement, the man pays the woman's family a bridewealth [[dower]] (''nakhafa'') for their food and other spending. The marriage, called ''futtu'', is complete with a marriage contract that mentions the dower, and is accompanied with a wedding event called ''karikompe''.{{Citation needed|date=November 2016}} The newly married couple has advisors. The man’s advisor is called the “khoussoumanta-yougo” and the woman’s is called “khoussoumanta-yakhare”. After one week of celebration, the women meet to show the gifts that the couple received from their parents mostly from the woman's mother.{{Cite web |title=Culture Et Tradition |year=2002 |publisher=Soninkara.com |accessdate=2006-04-05 |url=http://www.soninkara.com/main.php3?f=accueil |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060113021254/http://www.soninkara.com/main.php3?f=accueil |archivedate=2006-01-13 |df= }} Marriage across social strata and caste lines has been taboo, states Saskia Brand. But, in polygynous noble families, a noble could take a wife from the slave strata. ===Circumcision === The Soninke practise [[circumcision]] and call it ''birou''. Every afternoon, the boys who were circumcised the previous year organize ''tam-tams''{{clarify|date=February 2011}} for the new boys in order to prepare them psychologically. Throughout the circumcision ceremony, the boys to be circumcised sit around the “tambour” called “daïné”. The other teenagers of the village, young girls, women, men, and slaves form a circle around the boys. During this time the boys are surrounded with beautiful scarves called ''disa'' sing.{{Cite web |title=The circumcision among Soninke |url=http://www.soninkara.org/societe-soninkara/circoncision/index.php |accessdate=2006-04-28 |publisher=Soninkara.com |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061225180752/http://www.soninkara.org/societe-soninkara/circoncision/index.php |archivedate=2006-12-25 |df= }} The author Mamadou Soumare wrote “Above its traditional surgery, the ritual of circumcision makes in evidence, the physical endurance, the pain, the courage, in one word the personality of the child.” ====Female genital mutilation==== The Soninke people have long carried out [[female genital mutilation]] (FGM), also called female circumcision.{{cite journal | last=Ericksen | first=K. P. | title=Female Genital Mutilations in Africa | journal=Cross-Cultural Research | volume=23 | issue=1-4 | year=1989 | pages=182–204 | doi=10.1177/106939718902300104 }} The prevalence rate of FGM is higher among the Soninke than among neighbouring ethnic groups such as Wolof people and others,.{{cite journal | last=Ouldzeidoune | first=Nacerdine | last2=Keating | first2=Joseph | last3=Bertrand | first3=Jane | last4=Rice | first4=Janet | title=A Description of Female Genital Mutilation and Force-Feeding Practices in Mauritania: Implications for the Protection of Child Rights and Health | journal=PLOS One | volume=8 | issue=4 | year=2013 | page=e60594 | doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0060594 }} The practice is culturally done as a ritual of social acceptance, and sometimes assumed to be required for religious reasons. In Mauritania and Senegal, FGM of a child is illegal in contemporary law but continues because it is culturally sanctioned for young girls as young as one year old. According to the 2009 Report on Human Rights Practices by the US State Department, FGM practice among Soninke has included the most dangerous Type III mutilations.{{cite book|author=US State Department|title=Country Reports on Human Rights Practices 2009|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7NMXABwIjyAC&pg=PA554|year=2010|publisher=Government Printing Office|page=554}} ===Foods=== Breakfast foods include ''fonde'', porridge made of [[millet]], sugar, milk, and salt, and ''sombi'' porridge made of rice, millet or corn. For lunch ''demba tere'' and ''takhaya'' are very common, both containing rice and peanuts, frequent Soninke ingredients. ''Dere'', a stew, is a mixture of millet and beans.{{Cite web |title=Soninke Recipes |year=2002 |publisher=Soninkara.com |accessdate=2006-04-05 |url=http://www.soninkara.org/societe-soninkara/cuisine-soninke/index.php |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070220154506/http://www.soninkara.org/societe-soninkara/cuisine-soninke/index.php |archivedate=2007-02-20 |df= }} ==Economy== The Soninke traditionally engage in both trade and agriculture. During the rainy season, men and women both cultivate. However, women usually stay at home to cook and take care of their children. They also do other work, such as dyeing cotton material. Many early West African immigrants in France came from this ethnic group.{{cite news |url=http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m2005/is_1_33/ai_56027336 |accessdate=2006-04-28 |title=Willing Migrants: Soninke Labor Diasporas, 1848-1960 | work=Journal of Social History | first=R. Darrell | last=Meadows | year=1999}} The Soninke are an influential ethnic group in the Gambia, Senegal and Mali. ==See also== *[[Soninke language]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Bibliography== *{{en icon}} François Manchuelle, ''Origins of Black African Emigration to France : the Labor Migrations of the Soninke, 1948-1987'', Santa Barbara, University of California, 1987 (Thèse) *{{fr icon}} M. T. Abéla de la Rivière, ''Les Sarakolé et leur émigration vers la France'', Paris, Université de Paris V, 1977 (Thèse de 3 cycle) *{{fr icon}} Amadou Diallo, ''L’éducation en milieu sooninké dans le cercle de Bakel : 1850-1914'', Dakar, Université Cheikh Anta Diop, 1994, 36 p. (Mémoire de DEA) *{{fr icon}} Alain Gallay, « La poterie en pays Sarakolé (Mali, Afrique Occidentale) », ''Journal de la Société des Africanistes'', Paris, CNRS, 1970, tome XL, n° 1, p. 7-84 *{{fr icon}} Joseph Kerharo, « La pharmacopée sénégalaise : note sur quelques traitements médicaux pratiqués par les Sarakolé du Cercle de Bakel », ''Bulletin et mémoires de la Faculté mixte de médecine et de pharmacie de Dakar'', t. XII, 1964, p. 226-229 *{{fr icon}} Kanté Nianguiry, ''Contribution à la connaissance de la migration "soninké" en France'', Paris, Université de Paris VIII, 1986, 726 p. (Thèse de 3 cycle) *{{fr icon}} Michael Samuel, ''Les Migrations Soninke vers la France'', Paris, Université de Paris. (Thèse de 3 cycle) *{{fr icon}} Badoua Siguine, ''La tradition épique des forgerons soninké'', Dakar, Université de Dakar, 198?, (Mémoire de Maîtrise) *{{fr icon}} Badoua Siguine, ''Le surnaturel dans les contes soninké'', Dakar, Université de Dakar, 1983, 215 p. (Mémoire de Maîtrise) *{{fr icon}} Mahamet Timera, ''Les Soninké en France : d'un histoire à l'autre'', Karthala, 1996, 244 p. {{ISBN|2-86537-701-6}} *{{fr icon}} [[Louis Léon César Faidherbe]], ''Vocabulaire d'environ 1,500 mots français avec leurs correspondents en ouolof de Saint-Louis, en poular (toucouleur) du Fouta, en soninké (sarakhollé) de Bakel'', 1864, Saint-Louis, Imprimerie du Gouvernement, 1864, 70 p. *{{fr icon}} Louis Léon César Faidherbe, ''Langues sénégalaises : wolof, arabe-hassania, soninké, sérère, notions grammaticales, vocabulaires et phrases'', E. Leroux, 1887, 267 p. *{{fr icon}} Christian Girier, ''Parlons soninké'', l'Harmattan, Paris, 1996, {{ISBN|2-7384-3769-9}} *{{fr icon}} Rhonda L. Hartell, Alphabets de langues africaines, Unesco et Summer Institute of Linguistics, Dakar, 1993; *{{fr icon}} Direction de la promotion des langues nationales du Sénégal, Livret d'auto-formation en Soninké, éditions Kalaama-Edicef, 2001. ==External links== {{Commons category|Soninke}} *{{fr icon}} [http://www.diawara.org/soninkara/soninkara.php Site of the commune of Diawara, Sénégal] *{{fr icon}} [http://www.soobe.8m.net/fran_index.htm Soobe] - Association culturelle de Soninké en Egypte *{{fr icon}} [http://www.diaguily.org Diaguily] - Portail de Diaguily, ville soninké du sud de la Mauritanie *{{en icon}} [http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=snk Ethnologue] - Soninké language at Ethnologue *{{fr icon}} [http://www.soninkara.com/ Soninkara.com] - Portail de la communauté soninké *{{fr icon}} [http://www.soninkara.org/ Soninkara.org] - Société et Culture Soninké - Soninké News *{{en icon}} [http://www.asawan.org/ Asawan.org] - Soninke literature - free online library/bookstore {{navboxes| |list= {{Ethnic groups in Burkina Faso}} {{Ethnic groups in the Gambia}} {{Ethnic groups of Ghana}} {{Ethnic groups in Mali}} {{Ethnic groups in Mauritania}} {{Ethnic groups in Senegal}} {{Mandé peoples}} }} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Soninke People}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in Mali]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Burkina Faso]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Senegal]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in the Gambia]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Ghana]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Mauritania]] [[Category:African nomads]] [[Category:History of Africa]] [[Category:Muslim communities in Africa]] [[Category:Soninke people| ]]

{{Infobox military installation | name = Spinola Battery | native_name = Batterija ta' Spinola | location = [[St. Julian's]], [[Malta]] | image = | caption = | type = [[Artillery battery]] | coordinates = {{coord|35|55|15.8|N|14|29|34.2|E|type:landmark|display=inline}} | built = 1889–1894 | used = 1894–1940s | builder = [[British Empire]] | materials = [[Concrete]] | height = | fate = Demolished | battles = [[World War II]] | events = }}
'''Spinola Battery''' ({{lang-mt|Batterija ta' Spinola}}), also known as '''Fort Spinola''', was an [[artillery battery]] in [[St. Julian's]], [[Malta]]. It was built by the [[British Empire|British]] between 1889 and 1894, and it was demolished to make way for hotels and a yacht marina.
==History== Construction of Spinola Battery began in 1889 and was completed in 1894, at a cost of around £5000.<ref>{{mt icon}} {{cite book|last1=Guillaumier|first1=Alfie|title=Bliet u Rħula Maltin|date=1987|publisher=Valletta Publishing & Promotion Co. Ltd.|location=[[Valletta]]|page=707}}</ref> It was part of a new series of fortifications meant to house [[Breech-loading weapon|breech-loading (BL) guns]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Stephenson|first1=Charles|title=The Fortifications of Malta 1530–1945|date=2004|publisher=Osprey Publishing|isbn=1841766933|page=41|url=https://books.google.com.mt/books?id=XsQ1CdqvyqUC&pg=PA41&lpg=PA41#v=onepage&q&f=false|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141230225912/https://books.google.com.mt/books?id=XsQ1CdqvyqUC&pg=PA41&lpg=PA41#v=onepage&q&f=false|archivedate=2014-12-30|df=}}</ref>
Spinola Battery was located behind the [[Spinola Entrenchment]], an 18th-century bastioned [[Entrenchment (fortification)|entrenchment]] wall stretching from St. Julian's Bay to St. George's Bay.<ref>{{cite web|title=Spinola Bay to St Georges Bay Entrenchment|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1421.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=24 June 2015|date=28 June 2013}}</ref> It had a pentagonal shape, and was armed with four guns, including two [[BL 9.2 inch gun Mk I–VII|9.2-inch BL guns]]. Its armament was removed in 1907.<ref>{{cite web|title=9.2inch B.L.|url=http://www.victorianforts.co.uk/art/9_2inchBLGun.htm|website=Victorian Forts and Artillery|accessdate=24 June 2015}}</ref>
The battery was converted and developed into a hospital, known as the ''Spinola Hospital'', during World War I. It served as a hospital from 16 November 1915 till 27 April 1917. It was designed to serve for roughly 1000 patients, but during the war it had served for a maximum of 1168.<ref>[http://www.travelmalta.com/aztours/ANZAC%20experience%20-%20Arrival.pdf The Anzac experience in Malta]. p. 9.</ref> The battery saw use again in [[World War II]], when it was armed with [[QF 4.5-inch Mk I – V naval gun#Land use|4.5-inch anti-aircraft guns]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Debono|first1=Charles|title=The blitz on HMS Illustrious 70 years ago|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20110130/life-features/the-blitz-on-hms-illustrious-70-years-ago.347816|accessdate=24 June 2015|work=[[Times of Malta]]|date=30 January 2011}}</ref> It was severely damaged by aerial bombardment.
In 1969, it was used as a film sound studio, known as Intermed, later, as Brittania Studios. The studio was exactly situated behind the Milenium Chapel, now, a supermarket. Some of the films that made use of this sound stage were: Orca the killer whale, Zeppelin, Murpheys War, The Mcintosh man, Pulp, Raise the Titanic. Actors: Michael Cane, Mickey Roony, Charlotte Ramplin, Paul Newman, Peter O'Toole.
[[File:Malta - St. Julian's - Vjal Portomaso - Hilton + Portomaso Marina 02 ies.jpg|thumb|The site of the battery is now the Portomaso Marina]]
The Hilton Malta Hotel was built in 1967 on the site of the battery. The hotel and any remains of the battery were later completely demolished to make way for the [[Portomaso Marina]] and a new Hilton hotel.
==Further reading== *[http://www.scarletfinders.co.uk/190.html Details about Spinola Fort and conversion]
==See also== *[[Spinola Redoubt]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Batteries in Malta}}

Czech Republic
Austria | language = Slovak | budget = $110,433{{cite web |title=The Interpreter (Tlmocník) |url=https://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/intl/?page=&wk=2018W9&id=_fTHEINTERPRETERT01 |website=[[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate=14 August 2018}} }} '''''The Interpreter''''' ({{lang-sk|'''Tlmočník'''}}) is a 2018 Slovak [[drama film]] directed by [[Martin Šulík]]. It was selected as the Slovak entry for the [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Language Film]] at the [[91st Academy Awards]].{{cite web |url=http://newsnow.tasr.sk/culture/film-tlmocnik-to-compete-in-2019-oscars-race/ |title=Film Tlmocnik to Compete in 2019 Oscars Race |work=News Now |date=7 August 2018 |accessdate=8 August 2018}} ==Plot synopsis== In Vienna, retiree Georg meets an interpreter named Ali. The two men embark on a journey across Slovakia, encountering wartime survivors who will hopefully lead them to the Nazi officer that killed Ali's parents.{{cite web |url=https://www.screendaily.com/news/palestines-ghost-hunting-ukraines-donbass-join-foreign-language-oscar-submissions/5131442.article |title=Oscar foreign-language film race 2019: All the titles submitted so far |last=Dalton |first=Ben |date=30 August 2018 |publisher=[[Screen International|Screen Daily]] |access-date=30 August 2018}} ==Cast== * [[Jirí Menzel]] as Ali Ungár * [[Peter Simonischek]] as Georg Graubner * [[Zuzana Mauréry]] as Edita * [[Attila Mokos]] as Kysel Junior * [[Anna Rakovska]] as Truda ==See also== * [[List of submissions to the 91st Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film]] * [[List of Slovak submissions for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|7368554|The Interpreter}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Interpreter, The}} [[Category:2018 films]] [[Category:2010s drama films]] [[Category:Austrian films]] [[Category:Czech films]] [[Category:Slovak films]] [[Category:Slovak-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Martin Šulík]] [[Category:Austrian drama films]] [[Category:Czech drama films]] {{Slovakia-film-stub}} {{2010s-drama-film-stub}}

{{Primary sources|date=March 2007}} '''The KOLIN''' are a [[Hungarian indie]]-[[Hungarian pop|pop]] band best known for their hit song ''San Francisco''. The band was formed in 2007 in [[Budapest]]. Their music style is [[synthpop]] influenced with [[indie rock]] and [[new rave]] sounds. The band consists of Márkó Linczényi (vocals/synthesizer), Ágoston Iván (drums) and Ferigeri (bass). Their debut album called ''Yell Into The Kazzo''. It was released in 2008 by [[Universal Music Group]]. The KOLIN won the award for Best Hungarian Act at the 2009 and 2010 [[MTV Europe Music Awards]]. ==Perez Hilton's reaction== [[Perez Hilton]], the famous American [[celebrity]] blogger gave a positive review for San Francisco on his blogsite:
"We are LOVING loving LOVING this band called the KOLIN - from Hungary. Yes, Hungary! They sing in English, though. So you'll be able to understand what they're saying. We've never mention a band from Hungary before, and we are thrilled to pop our cherry with the KOLIN. If you like sweet, sexy, dirty, garage, disconess, then you will love the band! Think [[Scissor Sisters]] meets [[Gossip (band)|The Gossip]]. We think the Bay Area has a new anthem!!!"
==Discography== === Studio Albums=== * ''Yell Into The Kazoo'' (2008) * ''KRIXKRAX'' (2016) ==Videography== *"Jimmy" Directed by Danila Kostil (2008) - Winner of the [[Kecskeméti Animáció Film Fesztivál|KAFF]] Award for Best Music Video in 2011.''[http://www.kaff.hu/news/read/88 10. Kecskeméti Animációs Filmfesztivál 7. Európai Animációs Játékfilm Fesztivál]''. Kecskeméti Animáció Film Fesztivál. 2011. *"San Francisco" Directed by Danila Kostil (2009) ==Awards== * 2009: MTV Europe Music Awards/Best Hungarian Act * 2010: MTV Europe Music Awards/Best Hungarian Act ==See also== *[[Budapest indie music scene]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} * [http://quart.hu/cikk.php?id=4259/] Quart.hu Hungarian Language 10 October 2009. * [http://perezhilton.com/2009-03-13-watch-listen-from-hungary/] Perez Hilton 13 March 2009. ==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6m247SoleDk San Francisco Official Music Video ] * [http://www.myspace.com/thekolin/ the KOLIN Official Myspace Page ] * [http://ema.mtv.co.hu/szavazas/ EMA MTV Official Homepage ] * [http://zene.hu/20100505_the_kolin/ Zene.hu the KOLIN Biography ] * [http://www.universalmusic.hu/ Universal Music Hungary ] {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2011}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kolin}} {{Budapest indie music scene}} [[Category:Hungarian electronic musicians]] [[Category:Hungarian indie rock groups]] {{europe-band-stub}} {{hungary-stub}}

{{Infobox spaceflight | name = Yamal 101 (Ямал-101) | names_list = | image = | image_caption = | image_alt = | image_size = | mission_type = [[Communications satellite|Communication]] | operator = [[Gazprom Space Systems]] | Harvard_designation = | COSPAR_ID = 1999-047B | SATCAT = 25897 | website = | mission_duration = Failed after launch | spacecraft = Yamal 101 | spacecraft_type = Yamal 100 | spacecraft_bus = [[USP (satellite bus)|USP Bus]] | manufacturer = [[S. P. Korolev Rocket and Space Corporation Energia|RSC Energia]] (bus)
[[SSL (company)|Space Systems/Loral]] (payload) | launch_mass = {{convert|1360|kg|abbr=on}} | BOL_mass = | landing_mass = | dry_mass = | payload_mass = | dimensions = | power = 2200 | launch_date = {{start date|1999|09|06|16|36|00|7=Z}} | launch_rocket = [[Proton-K]]/[[Blok D|Blok-DM-2M]] | launch_site = [[Baikonur Cosmodrome|Baikonur]] [[Baikonur Cosmodrome Site 81|Site 81/23]] | launch_contractor = | deployment_from = | deployment_date = | entered_service = | disposal_type = Failed after launch | deactivated = | destroyed = | last_contact = September 6, 1999 | recovery_by = | recovery_date = | decay_date = | orbit_reference = [[Geostationary Orbit|GEO]] | orbit_regime = | orbit_longitude = 49°E | orbit_slot = | orbit_semimajor = | orbit_eccentricity = | orbit_periapsis = | orbit_apoapsis = | orbit_inclination = | orbit_period = | orbit_RAAN = | orbit_arg_periapsis = | orbit_mean_anomaly = | orbit_mean_motion = | orbit_repeat = | orbit_velocity = | orbit_epoch = | orbit_rev_number = | apsis = | trans_band = | trans_frequency = 12 [[C band (IEEE)|C band]] | trans_bandwidth = | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW = | programme = [[Yamal (satellite constellation)|Yamal Constellation]] | previous_mission = | next_mission = [[Yamal 102]] | insignia = | insignia_caption = | insignia_alt = | insignia_size = }} '''Yamal 101''' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: {{lang|ru|'''Ямал-101'''}}) was a [[geostationary orbit|geostationary]] [[communications satellite]] operated by [[Gazprom Space Systems|Gazkom]] and built by [[S. P. Korolev Rocket and Space Corporation Energia|RSC Energia]]. It was, along with [[Yamal 102]] the first communications satellite of the [[Yamal (satellite constellation)|Yamal]] program and the first iteration of the [[USP (satellite bus)|USP Bus]]. It was a {{convert|1360|kg|abbr=on}} satellite with 2200W of power (1300W available for the payload) on an unpressurized bus. It had eight [[SPT-70]] [[Electrically powered spacecraft propulsion|electric thrusters]] by [[OKB Fakel]] for [[Orbital station-keeping|station keeping]]. Its payload was 12 [[C band (IEEE)|C band]] equivalent [[Transponder (satellite communications)|transponders]] supplied by [[Space Systems Loral]]. ==History== It was launched along Yamal 102 September 6, 1999 at 16:36 UTC from [[Baikonur Cosmodrome|Baikonur]] [[Baikonur Cosmodrome Site 81|Site 81/23]] by a [[Proton-K]]/[[Blok D|Blok-DM-2M]] directly to [[geostationary orbit|GEO]]. But a failure in the electrical system at solar panel deployment meant that it was lost right after the successful launch. ==Rename of Yamal 102== After '''Yamal 101''' failure, [[Gazprom Space Systems|Gazkom]] registered [[Yamal 102]] as Yamal 101. This has caused significant confusion but the records are clear that the satellite that failed was, in fact, the original Yamal 101. ==See also== {{Portal |Spaceflight}} * [[Yamal 102]] – Twin satellite that was launched together and ended up commissioned into service with the Yamal 101 registration. * [[Yamal (satellite constellation)|Yamal]] – Communication satellite family operated by Gazprom Space Systems. * [[Gazprom Space Systems]] – Satellite communication division of the [[Russia]]n oil giant [[Gazprom]]. * [[USP (satellite bus)|USP Bus]] – The satellite bus on which Yamal 101 is based. * [[S. P. Korolev Rocket and Space Corporation Energia|RSC Energia]] – The designer and manufacturer of the Yamal 101 satellite. ==References== {{Reflist|2|refs= {{cite web |url=http://www.energia.ru/en/automatic/usp.html |title=Universal Space Platform |publisher=RSC Energia |access-date=2016-07-20}} {{cite web |last1=Krebs |first1=Gunter Dirk |title=RKK Energiya: USP (Victoria) |url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sat/energiya_usp.htm |website=Gunter's Space Page |accessdate=2016-07-20 |date=2015-10-16}} {{cite web |last1=Krebs |first1=Gunter Dirk |title=Yamal 101,
